text: So we're going to talk about primes
again. We know we love primes, and there's
all different types of primes;
we know there's infinitely many primes;
we know there's all little different
categories of primes - so I'm going to
show you another one,
it's called Wilson primes. There's only
three Wilson primes that we know of. So
let's write out the three Wilson
primes; I'll show you why these are
special types of primes: 5, 13 and 563.
Now actually they think there's
infinitely many Wilson primes but we've
only found three of them. So what's this
this special thing that they do that
other primes don't? Well one thing that
all primes do - I'll show you this - this
is what all primes can do; you have a
prime P minus 1, we're going to do a
factorial on it. Do you remember
factorial? So you're multiplying all the
numbers up to an including P minus 1; so

it'd be 1 times 2 times 3 times 4-
so if my
prime is 5 it'd be 1 times 2 times 3
times 4, ok. I'm now going to add one and
that is divisible by the original prime

P, and all primes do that. 
So in the case of
5 you would have 5 minus 1 factorial
plus 1, so what's that? We're talking 4
factorial plus 1. What is 4 factorial?
It's 1 times 2 times 3 times 4, and then
we add the 1, on that's 24. So 24 plus 1
is 25 and you can divide by 5, in fact
you can do that for any prime, that will
work for any prime. And it only works for
primes, it doesn't work for composite
numbers. We've talked about tests for
primes before, we talked about Fermat
primes and sometimes there
were Liars weren't there? There were some
numbers that weren't prime that passed
the test, they were lying to us. This is a
100% test for primes, only primes pass

it, composites fail. 
Let's have a-

let's do a composite.
- (Brady: Can I choose one?)

Oh, you're going to pick a big one are you?
We have
to do a factorial remember, this is the

problem.
- (Let's- can I, let's do 8.)
Right. So 8 minus 1 factorial then we add
1, right. So 7 factorial
plus 1. Okay, so we're going to do 7

factorial, so that is, hmm,
I wonder what that is...
5040. Oh don't show them that!
So 5040 plus 1. So 5041; but I'm saying
that's never going to be divisible by 8,
and I don't think it's going to be is it?
So we're going to divide that by 8 - and
it's not. You don't get a full number, a
whole number, for that. So- but that's
guaranteed; primes will give you a whole
number and composites would never give
you a whole number for that. Yeah, that's
called Wilson's theorem and it is a test
for primes. It's not great test for
primes because you have to do a
factorial and they get massive, so you'd
have to work out a massive factorial. If
it passes though, it is a prime. So all
primes pass that test, the Wilson
primes are special because they pass
the test twice over; you can actually do
it twice over. So you can divide by the
prime and then divide by the prime again
and you get a whole number. So all
primes pass the test once but only
these three that we found manage to do
that twice over. I'll show you I mean,
let's do the 5. Well we did the 5
already didn't we? So we got 25,
5 minus 1 factorial plus 1. So we
ended up with 25 so we know you can
divide by 5; so you know 25 divided by
5 is equal to 5. And all I'm saying is
you can divide by the prime again;
so obviously 5 divided by 5 is 1, so that

would work. Other primes wouldn't do
that.
So we see a prime passing it once and

then failing the second time. 
- (I want to see 13.)
D'you wanna do 13 first? Let's do it with
13 and see what we get. So we're looking
at 12 factorial plus 1, let's see what

you've got; 12 factorial, 
brilliant, big number:

479 million 1600.
- (Plus 1)
Plus 1, all right. Let's see if the

prime divides it, do you think it's
likely?

- (Divide it by 13...)
- Yep it divides
perfectly, wonderful. But all primes do
that, does it do it twice? Yes it does.
It does it twice! So 13 is a Wilson prime
as is the last one I've got here, 563.
Do you want to see something fail; just to

check? Pick a prime.
- (7?)
Yes, let's do 7; small
isn't it? Right, first I work out how to
clear something...right,
7. So we need 7 minus 1 factorial and
then we're going to add 1, so we're
talking 6 factorial plus 1. Well I know 6
factorial is 720 - if I'm feeling

confident I'm going to say that's 721.
Let's see
if it works. Now if I divide by 7 which
is the prime...works, 103. Can I do it a
second time? I don't think it's going to
happen though. Divide by 7 again then
and no it's not going to work. So
there! So that's the- that's kind of
nice, it's a nice nice little prime
number fact. There's no great use for it
but why do we have to do everything for
application? This is just a great little
prime number fact. Now that we know what
Wilson primes are, let's have a look
about- of the Wilson lemma. That was
that was just the original result, that
was just this one here. So I'm saying
that primes can do this at least once;

let's just see if that's true.
So we're going
to prove that, so we're going to get some
more brown paper?
...no sneaky composite numbers; no

checked large
numbers for this.
